awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Sustainable Chemistry from Combined Inorganic and Organic Waste Precursors
awd_abstract_narration:
Agricultural and petroleum companies produce a tremendous amount of byproducts that is both costly to dispose of and potentially environmentally damaging.  This NSF award supports research to develop new chemistry to combine waste from these key American industries and to turn these waste materials into polymers/plastics that are useful for consumer products.  By developing novel approaches to recyclable polymers/plastics that are affordable and sustainable, this project aims to benefit society by significantly (1) reducing the environmental damage caused by using non-sustainable plastics, (2) reducing the cost of consumer products in many different markets, and (3) decreasing the amount of waste for which agricultural companies and petroleum refineries pay for disposal.  K-12 teachers are offered opportunities to learn about sustainable chemistry to use in lessons in K-12 science classes.  To increase participation in science, technology, engineering and mathematics fields, this project provides research opportunities to technical and predominantly undergraduate college students and educational activities to engage underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students.

Polymeric organic and inorganic wastes (POIWs) generated by agricultural and petroleum refining processes have been explored as additives for conventional construction materials, but such products are merely physically blended materials, which are inherently prone to multiple, inescapable environmental deterioration pathways, including fragmentation, leaching, corrosion, and biological degradation.  This research is developing chemistry to form covalent bonds between these POIWs and the components of traditional macromolecular compounds to confer upon them significantly greater strength and environmental durability.  The objective is being pursued by covalently crosslinking agricultural waste-derived polymeric materials (such as lignocellulosic materials) with petroleum refining waste-derived materials (e.g., sulfur).

por.por_cntn:
Agriculture is the most essential human activity, but it produces over five billion tons of pre-consumer biowaste annually. This biowaste is made mostly of cellulose and lignin. Nearly all of the major food crops grown on Earth produce significant quantities of biowaste (straw, corn cobs, rice hulls, etc.) and there are limited uses for the waste.

 

Sulfur is another waste product, and it comes from the energy-generation industry. Environmental regulations limit the sulfur content in gasoline to 10 ppm, so the petroleum industry removes 60 million tons of sulfur from petroleum every year.

 

In this National Science Foundation (NSF) funded work, we explored ways to combine the biomass and sulfur waste products to make building materials like plastic and cement. This research was very successful. Using some known chemical reactions, lignin was modified and reacted with sulfur by a process called inverse vulcanization to give some composites that are remeltable, making them very easy to recycle. Unfortunately, these lignin composites were not very durable. When cellulose was modified in a similar way and reacted with sulfur, however, the resultant composites had flexural strength that is in the same range as traditional cement products. Additional composites were made from the reaction of sulfur with other plant- and animal- derived, potentially renewable starting materials like terpenoids, amino acids, plant oils, guaiacol (a molecule made from lignin) and fatty acids (derived from plant oil or animal fat). From these studies, some composites were made that had almost twice the strength of traditional cement, while being made from renewable materials and waste products. The composites are also usually very easy to recycle by melting them down and re-shaping them in molds without their losing mechanical strength after the recycling process. These sulfur-containing cements also have good resistance to acid and surface damage can be thermally healed.

 

In the course of this work, new mechanisms for reaction of sulfur with organics were discovered. Previous work required an olefin (alkene) chemical group to react with sulfur. A new reaction mechanism for olefins with sulfur was discovered that led to cyclization of terpenoids, a pathway that significantly influences the strength of composites made from sulfur and terpenoids.

 

Two new routes to make sulfur-organic composites were developed in the research as well. These reactions allow sulfur to react not only with olefins, but also with carbon-halogen bonds in aryl halides or with carbon-hydrogen bonds in anisole derivatives. These discoveries make it possible to use many more compounds as starting materials for making sulfur-organic composites than was possible using the previously-known polymerization mechanisms like inverse vulcanization.

 

The research work described above led to publication of 22 peer-reviewed papers in scientific journals. These papers had a notable impact on the scientific community. One of the papers was among the most downloaded of 2019 in its journal, one of the studies was picked as a top-10 paper of 2020 in its journal, and four of the articles were featured in the news at sites like Science News, Plastics Today and Advanced Science News.

 

One of the overarching goals of the project was to have broader impacts on society and sustainability. Some of these broader impacts come from the new materials that were made in the project. Entirely new classes of composites comprising lignin, cellulose, terpenoid, fatty acid, plant oil, amino acid and sulfur were developed. The new way to react sulfur directly with aryl halides and anisole derivatives was also important to science because now it is known that other compounds with these chemical groups can be made into polymers by reaction with sulfur. There is already industrial interest in the lignin and cellulose composites made in this project, and the hope is that the composites will find immediate commercial applications due to the affordability of the starting materials and the strength of materials for construction and manufacturing processes.

 

Additional broader impact of the research comes from education and spreading knowledge learned in the project to as many people as possible. During this project, the several students were able to do their research thanks to the NSF support. These students also contributed to broader science education as they wrote some important review articles to raise awareness of specific issues that are pressing in sustainable materials research. Specifically, these articles were about 1) plastic recycling, 2) starch-derived food packaging as a replacement for petrochemical plastics, 3) lignin as a replacement for nonrenewables in plastic production, 4) the use of plant oil-derived fatty acids to make plastics and 5) how sulfur can be used to make more efficient batteries for energy storage.
